At that time, this realm was extraordinarily adorned, and the entire great assembly rejoiced and danced with joy.
Vajra Wisdom Bodhisattva asked, and the Buddha answered below:

I observe with the Buddha eye that within the afflictions of greed, anger, and delusion of all sentient beings there is the wisdom of the TathÄgata, the eye of the TathÄgata, and the body of the TathÄgata, sitting cross-legged, majestic and unmoving.
Good sons!
Although all sentient beings are in the various destinies, within the body of afflictions there is the TathÄgatagarbha, always unstained, endowed with virtuous characteristics, no different from me.
Moreover, good sons!
It is like a person with the heavenly eye who sees the bodies of TathÄgatas sitting cross-legged within unopened flowers, and by removing the withered flowers they become revealed.
In this way, good sons!
The Buddha sees the TathÄgatagarbha of sentient beings and wishes to cause it to blossom, so he expounds the sÅ«tras and Dharma, eliminating afflictions and revealing the Buddha-nature.
Good sons!
The dharmas of all buddhas are such that whether a buddha appears in the world or does not appear in the world, the tathÄgatagarbha of all sentient beings is always abiding and unchanging.

However, because those sentient beings are covered by afflictions, the TathÄgata appears in the world and widely preaches the Dharma for them, eliminating their defilements and enabling them to attain omniscience.
Each parable is followed by a verse.
Second, Good sons!
It is like pure honey in a mountain tree, guarded by countless swarms of bees.
At that time, there was a person with skillful wisdom and means who first removed the bees and then took the honey, using it as he wished to benefit those near and far.
The following is a summary of the meaning.

The honey is a metaphor for the tathÄgatagarbha, the bees are a metaphor for afflictions, and the person is a metaphor for the TathÄgata. Removing the bees is a metaphor for expounding the Dharma to eliminate afflictions.
Third, Good sons!
It is like rice that has not yet been husked.
The poor and foolish despise it as something to be discarded. Once the chaff is removed, it should be used for cooking.

The combined explanation says, The chaff is a metaphor for afflictions, and the rice is a metaphor for the TathÄgata's knowledge and insight. The teaching removes afflictions and purifies omniscience, becoming the supreme perfect enlightenment in all worlds.
Fourth, Next, good men!
It is like true gold falling into an impure place, hidden and invisible.
Even after years pass, the true gold is not destroyed, but no one knows about it.
One with the heavenly eye tells the crowd,
In this impurity there is true gold treasure. You can take it out and use it as you wish.
The Dharma combination is known by analogy.
Fifth, Next, good men!
It is like a poor family with a treasure trove of precious treasures, and the treasure trove cannot say, 'I am here.'
Since they do not know it themselves and there is no one to tell them, they cannot open this treasure trove of precious treasures.

All sentient beings are also like this. The power of the TathÄgata's knowledge and insight, the great treasure of the Dharma, is within their bodies, but they do not hear or know of it. They are addicted to the five desires, transmigrate through birth and death, and experience immeasurable suffering.
Therefore, the buddhas appear in the world to open the treasure of the TathÄgata's Dharma within their bodies, and with unobstructed eloquence they become great benefactors.
Sixth, Moreover, good man!
It is like an Ämra fruit, whose inner seed is indestructible. If planted in the ground, it becomes a great king of trees.

It is like a person carrying a genuine gold statue to another country, fearing robbery on the dangerous road, wrapping it in filthy rags to prevent recognition.
This person suddenly dies on the road, and the gold statue is abandoned in the wilderness. Travelers stepping on the trail all think it is impure.
One who has attained the heavenly eye sees a genuine gold statue in the filthy rags, and immediately takes it out, and everyone pays homage.
There is the subtle and precious treasury of the TathÄgata.
Eighth, Moreover, good man!
It is like a woman who is poor, lowly, ugly, despised by the people, yet she conceives a noble child who will become a sage-king ruling the four continents.
This person does not know, and throughout the years always thinks of giving birth to an inferior child.

The commentary below nine, leaving extremes and conforming to the middle explains the sutra's far removed from the two extremes, abiding in the middle way, which is the same as the text below pervading all minds.

The commentary has two parts:
First, explaining the transcendence of extremes, and second, explaining the abiding in the middle.

First, the sutra says transcending extremes, but it is not known what these are, so the Jin edition is cited, and the following explanation is taken. Four kinds are briefly mentioned, equating them with all.

Contaminated and pure are based on delusions, bondage and liberation are common to delusions and karma, existence and non-existence are common to phenomena and principles, and identity and difference are based on mind and objects.
Why are there these?
It is said that in attaining enlightenment, once subtle thoughts are transcended, false delusions are exhausted, and the Dharma body and wisdom are manifested as pure.
If one has this view, one is not yet free from extremes.

Therefore, the above sutra says, If there is one who sees right enlightenment, liberation, and freedom from defilements, not attached to anything in the world, that is not the eye of realizing the Way.
Now, understanding that the essence of delusions is originally empty, and there is nothing to be purified later, one thus transcends the two extremes.
Moreover, because defilement and purity interpenetrate, there is no attachment, which is called transcending extremes.
As for bondage and liberation, it means that one was formerly always bound by afflictions and karmic actions, wandering without end, but now attaining enlightenment and being completely liberated.
If one has this view, it is abiding in extremes.
The wisdom of enlightenment understands that one has never been bound, so how can there be liberation?
Without bondage and without liberation, there is neither delight nor aversion, so one can attain transcendence.
As for the words supreme that apply to both phenomena and principles, if one formerly considered afflictions to exist, now one understands afflictions to be empty;
formerly one considered the mind to be empty, now one knows the wondrous existence.
Moreover, true bliss originally exists, but one loses it and does not know it;
false suffering originally is empty, but one obtains it and is not aware of it.
Today one finally understands that emptiness is false suffering and existence is nirvana. If one knows in this way, one has not yet transcended extremes.

Furthermore, afflictions, karma, and suffering originally exist but now do not, and enlightenment and the Buddha's body originally did not exist but now exist, and so on. All of these are dharmas of the three times.
The nature of bodhi does not belong to the three times, therefore existence and non-existence in the three times are all included in the extremes.
True wisdom accords with principle and transcends the three times, therefore it is free from the two extremes of existence and non-existence, and so forth.
There are two kinds of identity and difference:
First, if mind and object are not understood, there are two; if they are in accord, there is one, which also becomes an extreme.
Second, if there is a difference between sentient beings and Buddhas, and now one understands the one nature, this is also called an extreme.
Now, in this, there is neither duality nor non-duality, and there is also no one with great wisdom who sees well, because one skillfully abides in accordance with principle.
To speak of being free from these extremes and so forth means that arising and ceasing, coming and going, birth and death, the dependent and the correct are all called extremes.
Moreover, duality and non-duality are also called extremes.
Now, in one accord with bodhi, everything is tranquil, therefore it is said to be far removed.
The commentary below not dwelling in partiality explains abiding in the middle way.
However, it raises difficulties and gives rise to the accord with the middle below.
The text says:
If one is apart from the extremes but not yet free from the extremes, there is still grasping and abandoning.
Therefore, the commentary explains:
Not dwelling one-sidedly is called being apart from the extremes, not seeing the existence of extremes that can be separated.
It means not dwelling one-sidedly in defilement, because the nature of defilement is empty;
